title: $A follows Chinese stocks lower
text:
Wed, Aug 19, 2015, 8:53 AM AEST - Australia Markets open in 1 hr 7 mins $A follows Chinese stocks lower AAP â€“ 1 hour 13 minutes ago Recommend Print 
The Australian dollar is struggling to gain any ground, weighed down by Chinese share market volatility and an imminent Federal Reserve interest rate rise. 
At 0700 AEST on Wednesday, the local unit was trading at 73.43 US cents, down from 73.47 cents on Tuesday. 
The currency has steadily fallen from yesterday's high of 73.85 US cents after the Shanghai share market fell more than six per cent on Tuesday on worries than the Chinese government won't intervene any further to prop up its share market or the economy. 
LTG GoldRock director Andrew Barnett said China and the chance that the US Federal Reserve will make its first interest rate increase in nine years are bad news for the Aussie dollar. 
"The two elephants in the room for the Aussie to go lower is the US Fed raising rates - I think that's a better than 50-50 chance now - and if China continues to look like it's slowing with stock market uncertainty and lower commodity prices," he said. 
Mr Barnett said the two key events for the market in the next 24 hours was the release of US inflation figures for July, on Wednesday night Sydney time, and the Federal Reserve minutes early on Thursday morning. 
He said that if the inflation figures are a bit better than expected then the Australian dollar will lose more ground, because it increases the change of a Fed rate hike. 
CURRENCY SNAPSHOT AT 0700 AEST ON WEDNESDAY 
One Australian dollar buys: 
* 73.43 US cents, from 73.47 cents on Tuesday 
* 91.35 Japanese yen, from 91.37 yen 
* 66.66 euro cents, from 66.35 euro cents 
* 111.26 New Zealand cents, from 111.57 NZ cents 
* 46.89 British pence, from 47.20 pence 
(*Currency closes taken at 1700 AEST previous local session) 
Source: IRESS
